Award.AwardTitle: Searching and Discovering New Physics with Run-2 on ATLAS Experiment of LHC
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Standard Model (SM) of elementary particle physics gives an excellent description of the strong and electroweak interactions, the forces that influence the structure and behavior of elementary particles such as the proton and neutron. The SM also describes most of what we know about the visible matter in the Universe. The Higgs Boson, discovered at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in Switzerland, was the last ingredient in this theory. Yet the overwhelming success of the SM seems only to emphasize its limitations. There are many open questions remaining. Why are there three families of quarks, elementary particles that make up the proton and neutron, and leptons, elementary particles such as the electron and muon? What is the nature of space-time itself? Do the extra dimensions suggested by string theories and string- inspired models really exist? Where do dark energy and dark matter fit into our current picture of the universe? Answers to these key questions can only be found by including new physics beyond the SM. This group will work with the ATLAS experiment at the LHC to look for this new physics by searching for new particles emerging from proton-proton collisions. An exciting feature of this program is that a number of undergraduate and Masters students from Fresno and other Cal State institutions will be involved. They will participate not only in this analysis thrust but will also gain hands-on experience helping in a variety of hardware projects from other ATLAS collaborators.

In this proposed research plan, Professor Gao and his group at California State University, Fresno will continue to search for particles from new physics in di-jet events. The use of di-jet data as a way to search for new physics is a classic approach with a long history, and requires precise understanding of the jet energy scales expected from the SM. The PI has considerable experience in jet physics and is well aware of the challenges this presents. He intends to build on successful prior work in which new variables were identified that should discriminate a potential new physics signal from QCD. Such variables, by construction, use the radiation patterns from partons in a multi-variate analysis of the structures observed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ATLAS (A Toroidal LHC ApparatuS) experiment at LHC is poised to address some of the deepest questions in the field of particle physics. The answers we will learn could change our view of the universe. ATLAS discovered the Higgs (“God” particle) in 2012 which was named by Science magazine as the 2012 “Breakthrough of the Year” and resulted in the award of 2013 Nobel Physics Prize to the two theoretical physicists who developed the Higgs theory in 1960s. The ATLAS collaboration consists of ~3000 physicists from ~190 institutions of 38 countries all over the world. About 500 physicists from ~45 US national labs and universities are currently working on ATLAS. They are from 4 national labs (Argonne National Lab (ANL), Brookhaven National Lab (BNL), Lawrence Berkeley National Lab (LBNL), and Stanford Linear Accelerator Center (SLAC)), and many top research universities (U. of Chicago, Columbia, Duke, Harvard, Michigan, MIT, UPenn, Stanford, UT-Austin, Washington, Wisconsin, Yale, etc.).

The CSU is the largest university system in the country with 23 campuses and ~490,000 students, including very large minority and first-generation college student populations. CSU Fresno joined ATLAS in 2007 as the only CSU campus on ATLAS or CMS, and was the only CSU campus involved in the Higgs discovery. This was also the first research a CSU campus was involved in which has resulted in a Nobel Prize. To provide the outstanding ATLAS opportunity to a wider CSU community, Gao (PI of this proposal) has been building up the CSU Nuclear and Particle Physics Consortium (NUPAC) since 2008. CSU NUPAC is a consortium of CSU campuses which provide support to their students who are interested in particle physics and ATLAS.  It now consists of 19 campuses: Bakersfield, Channel Islands, Chico, Dominguez Hills, East Bay, Fresno, Humboldt, Long Beach, Los Angeles, Northridge, Pomona, Sacramento, San Bernardino, San Diego, San Francisco, San Luis Obispo, San Marcos, Sonoma, and Stanislaus. CSU Fresno has been the center of NUPAC.

The CSU Fresno ATLAS group consists of one faculty (Yongsheng Gao, PI), one postdoc (Harinder Bawa), three IT engineers (Jay Fowler, Geoff King, and John Wagenleitner), one visiting Ph.D student from China (Wei Ding from Tsinghua University who is supported by his home institutions in China to work in Fresno with the CSU Fresno ATLAS group), 3 Master students (Jason Gruzdas, Anand Saggu, and Jennifer Tyler) and 2 undergraduate students (Will Barden and Gabriel Sotto). The group’s activities on ATLAS includes: new physics searches with dijet final states, ATLAS MC validation, build first US ATLAS computing cluster on cloud to explore cloud solution for ATLAS, education and outreach, etc.

 

The activities of the CSU Fresno ATLAS group include: new physics searches with dijet final states, developing first US ATLAS cloud cluster and first US ATLAS Shared Tier 3 facility on cloud for Run 3, coordinator of ATLAS MC Validation, Distributed Analysis Support Team (DAST) shifts, ATLAS control room data quality shifts, contribution to operation and monitoring of pixel detector, trigger, Phase II pixel upgrade, etc. Since 2015, the members of CSU Fresno ATLAS group have given a total of over 200  presentations at ATLAS WG meetings, contributed to 17 ATLAS Communication Notes, 6 ATLAS Conference Notes and proceedings, and 6 ATLAS publications in searching for new physics with dijet final states in PL, PRD, and PRL. In addition, members of CSU Fresno ATLAS group have given 10 presentations at international and national conferences.

Every fall and spring semester since 2015, the PI has been offering two online courses across the NUPAC campuses to prepare new CSU students to work at CERN. The CSU students worked on ATLAS research projects at CERN move on to teaching, high-tech companies, and physics Ph.D programs (Brown, U. of Colorado at Boulder, Purdue, UCB, UCD, UCLA, UCSD, UCSC, Indiana, Umass at Lowell, USC, Purdue, Wisconsin, etc.). This is significantly higher than the ~20% fraction of other physics majors from CSU campuses to enter into Ph.D programs. When students worked at CERN, they also attended the famous CERN Summer Student Lecture Series given by top physicists from all over the world. The ATLAS working experience prepares CSU students for their personal and professional success in an increasingly competitive, global, and multi-cultural society.
